comment.author: 29455905@N00
comment._content: No, this is a street.  At left, an elevated section of metro or elevated train over the road.  Under the track, streetcars are running.  At right there is a stair that looks like an access to an station.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks tgva325 for your sharp observation of the scene.  We'll fix the title in the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 75421381@N00
comment._content: I do not think this is Boston. As far as I know, there have only been a couple old elevated streetcar lines, and I do not recall any of them looking like this. The second paragraph on the link below indicates that this picture may well have been taken in Sioux City: genforum.genealogy.com/sellon/messages/101.html

comment.author: 29455905@N00
comment._content: As far as I can see, the streetcars are running UNDER the bridge, which is for an elevated electric train, like those in New York, Chicago and Boston.  Sioux City elevated railway was closed in 1899 and as far as I know, it hadn´t streetcars tracks under it.

comment.author: 28699220@N06
comment._content:
It could certainly be Boston. The sign in the upper right references the  Boston Candy Store. Also, there were elevated railways in Boston beyond just the portion of the Green and Red Lines that remain above ground and elevated. What's now the Orange Line was at one point elevated, too. The Essex Street station was a copper-clad building, now preserved at the Trolley Museum in Kennebunkport, Maine. It would be interesting to see if the steel girders matched the preserved station. 

That said, if this is Boston, it's most likely near North Station.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Some discussion of this on a messaging board: www.subchat.com/readflat.asp?Id=559166&p=1#559715

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
Key info from the message board confirms New York City, and 2nd Avenue el.

"Posted by Elkeeper on Sun Jan 27 17:33:57 2008 ...  You can tell it's the 2nd Ave el by the structure, especially the pillars. And, yes, the photo does appear to be taken from a station. ... How about 1st Ave looking north towards 23rd St.  ..."

comment.author: 77975599@N03
comment._content: This El is to long to be N. Station.  This photo looks like the old El on Washington Street in the Roxbury area.  That long section out of Forest Hills had trolleys running under.  Yes I agree, it also looks like the 2nd Ave El in NY, they were pretty much the same structure design.
